name: AI Safety quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: What it’s trying to achieve (plain language)
roleShapes: Research engineering (tools, eval pipelines, infra for safety)
What a good fit often looks like (signals)
Motivated by high-stakes downside risk + can tolerate uncertainty/debate
Drawn to either: technical challenge, governance complexity, or enabling infrastructure/community
OK with long feedback loops (or choose Experiment C to make it concrete fast)
Robert Miles — “Intro to AI Safety, Remastered” (video)
Optional alt if they prefer reading: 80,000 Hours AI safety researcher career review
AGI Safety Fundamentals (reading group + discussion + project)
BlueDot Impact AI courses (technical safety / governance)
SPAR — a part-time remote program explicitly structured around impactful research projects with mentors in AI safety/policy.
Optional alt (bigger commitment): MATS (intensive mentored research program)
Toe-in-the-water step: pick 2–3 projects you could imagine doing; write 2 lines each (interest + feasibility)
Tiny scanning method (10–25 min): collect 8–12 interesting roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.
Candidate wants reality-checks on what the work looks like
Candidate is only looking for a quick interest test (use Robert Miles instead)
Skim sections: “what the work involves” + “who is a good fit” + write 3 bullets: “what matches me / what doesn’t.”
One-line pitch: An 8-week reading-group-style on-ramp used widely in the community: concepts, discussion, and a project component.
Candidate is interested and wants deeper understanding + community discussion
Candidate has no bandwidth for weekly participation (use Experiment A instead)
Commitment: Medium (5–15h/wk) (or set to Light if your cohorts are lighter; adjust later)
Read the curriculum/application page and see if week 1–2 feels exciting (not intimidating).
Card 5 — BlueDot Impact: AI Safety / AI Governance courses
Recommendation name: BlueDot Impact — AI courses (AI Safety / AI Governance tracks)
One-line pitch: Cohort-based courses that help people understand the field and meet peers; good default “structured exposure.”
Candidate wants structured learning + peers; not ready for a research fellowship yet
Candidate leans governance/policy OR wants a “less technical” entry option
Candidate is explicitly seeking a mentored project output now (use SPAR)
Pick one track (technical safety vs governance) and check cohort timing vs bandwidth.
Card 6 — SPAR (Supervised Program for Alignment Research)
Recommendation name: SPAR — Supervised Program for Alignment Research
One-line pitch: Part-time, remote, mentored projects designed to produce work that contributes to AI alignment/safety—good “measurable-good” project pathway.
Candidate wants to do something real (not just learn)
Candidate benefits from mentorship + defined projects
Candidate needs a push past impostor syndrome / “I’m not ready”
Candidate can’t realistically commit to the time window, even part-time
Browse the current/most recent projects; shortlist 2–3 you’d genuinely apply to and write 2 lines each (interest + feasibility).
Recommendation name: MATS Program (Mentored AI Safety Training)
One-line pitch: Intensive mentored research training; a serious step for people aiming at research entry.
Candidate is strongly research-leaning and wants a high-commitment path
Candidate is open to temporary relocation / intensive schedule
Candidate is unsure about the field (start with A/B or SPAR)
Fit gate: Requires relocation (if a given cohort is in-person; keep this conservative)
Check the apply page and cohort details; sanity-check dates/relocation feasibility.
One-line pitch: A high-signal job board with many EA-aligned roles; good for building intuition and spotting real orgs/roles.
Candidate is ready to make roles concrete or is motivated by seeing real openings
Candidate wants a practical bridge from interest → action
Candidate is very early and gets overwhelmed by job posts (use Experiment A first)
Do the 10–25 min scan: collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.
One-line pitch: AI-safety-specific curated jobs list; great for quickly seeing the org ecosystem.
Candidate wants “AI safety only” without sifting broader EA jobs
Candidate wants to learn org landscape quickly
Candidate is not at job-search stage and would spiral into comparison
Same scan method: 8–12 roles → 3 interesting roles → 2 repeating skill gaps.
One-line pitch: Broader than jobs: fellowships, programs, events, volunteering—useful to find “entry ramps.”
Candidate is earlier-stage and wants programs/projects not only jobs
Candidate is exploring multiple cause areas and wants a single “opportunities surface”
Candidate gets overwhelmed by breadth (use one concrete program card instead)
Search “AI safety” and save 3 opportunities that match your constraints/bandwidth.
[EA-canonical] EA Funds — Long-Term Future Fund: https://funds.effectivealtruism.org/funds/far-future Effective Altruism Funds
[EA-adjacent] Coefficient Giving (formerly Open Philanthropy): https://www.openphilanthropy.org/ AP News+1
[EA-adjacent] Alignment Research Center (ARC): https://alignment.org/ Alignment Research Center
[EA-adjacent] Machine Intelligence Research Institute (MIRI): https://intelligence.org/ MIRI
[EA-adjacent] AI Safety Camp: https://www.aisafety.camp/ AI Safety Camp
[Field] UK AI Security Institute (AISI): https://www.aisi.gov.uk/ AI Security Institute
Robert Miles — “Intro to AI Safety, Remastered” (video):
80,000 Hours — AI safety researcher career review:
AGI Safety Fundamentals — curriculum & application (Alignment Forum):

name: Animal × AI quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: 1) What it’s trying to achieve (plain language)
roleShapes: Applied ML for wild animal welfare: human–wildlife conflict mitigation, monitoring welfare indicators (e.g., vocalizations), detection/early warning systems. (Rethink Priorities)
AI in farmed animal systems: how AI in agriculture/aquaculture changes welfare (sometimes better, sometimes worse), plus interventions to steer it. (Rethink Priorities)
AI for animal advocacy orgs: LLM-enabled research workflows, message testing, supporter comms, grantwriting support, ops automation (done carefully). (Faunalytics)
Research & strategy at think tanks (what AI applications are promising, where are risks/unknowns). (Rethink Priorities)
Programs / community / hackathons for building tools and pipelines for animal protection. (Electric Sheep)
3) What a “good fit” often looks like (signals)
You like concrete technical leverage (data/ML) and you’re motivated by animals.
You’re comfortable with “applied + messy” domains (datasets, field conditions, imperfect metrics).
You can hold a balanced stance: “AI can help” and “AI can harm if used carelessly.” (Animal Charity Evaluators)
Animal Charity Evaluators — “The impacts of AI on animal advocacy” (high-level framing of upsides/risks; good first map). (Animal Charity Evaluators)
Rethink Priorities — AI for human–wildlife conflict mitigations (concrete examples; “here’s what AI-for-animals can look like”). (Rethink Priorities)
Optional alt (if they want “how advocates already use AI”)
Faunalytics — “AI and Animal Advocacy” (survey-style view of current usage patterns). (Faunalytics)
Rethink Priorities series: “How AI is affecting farmed aquatic animals” (deep dive on innovation → deployment → welfare effects; very “EA research-y”). (Rethink Priorities)
AI×Animals Fellowship (8-week remote program focused on AI × animal welfare careers). (Effective Altruism)
Futurekind AI Fellowship (12-week program on using AI for animal protection & environment; listed on EA Opportunities). (Effective Altruism)
(These structured programs are newer; I’m including them because they’re explicitly advertised in EA channels, but they’re not as long-established as core 80k/AAC resources.) (Effective Altruism)
Experiment C — project pathway (make it concrete; good for “I need a push”)
Canonical pick (low barrier, EA-aligned research contribution)
Use a Rethink Priorities “AI for animals” angle to produce a small artifact:
1–2 page scoping note (“which AI application + what welfare mechanism + what uncertainties?”)
or a lightweight literature/landscape map that could be shared with an org/funder. (Rethink Priorities)
Felidae Fund — volunteer AI/ML specialist processing camera imagery for animal population research (explicit volunteer role with real use). Felidae Conservation Fund+1
Faunalytics volunteering (if the person’s contribution is in the “research tooling / analysis” lane that directly supports advocates). Faunalytics
Pick one subdomain (e.g., “wildlife conflict detection,” “aquaculture AI welfare risks,” “LLM research tooling for advocates”).
Find one anchor piece (from Experiment A/B), then write 10 bullets: “promising application → mechanism → biggest risk/unknown → what a small project could be.”
Experiment D — job-board exploration (bridge theory → action)
80,000 Hours job board (filter for animal welfare, or AI/data roles in adjacent orgs).
Animal Advocacy Careers job board (search for data/tech roles; also helps you learn org landscape). (Animal Advocacy Careers)
EA Opportunities (often has fellowships/programs/projects that aren’t “jobs”). (Effective Altruism)
Collect 8–12 roles → label role type (ML / research / ops / policy) → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps → turn that into a direction + next step.
Program implementation & field ops (distribution, logistics, monitoring)
Research & evaluation (development econ, epidemiology, cost-effectiveness, RCTs)
Policy and government implementation (health systems, procurement, public finance)
Entrepreneurship / founding new orgs (esp. “evidence-to-scale” nonprofits) (80,000 Hours)
3) What a “good fit” often looks like (signals)
You’re motivated by measurable impact and are OK with “unsexy” operational realities (supply chains, compliance, systems)
You like working with messy real-world constraints and still making steady progress
You enjoy evidence and tradeoffs (not only “what’s morally urgent” but also “what works”) (80,000 Hours)
Experiment A — introductory resource (< 1 hour): wide overview + test interest
80,000 Hours problem profile: Health in poor countries (Global health) (read/skim) (80,000 Hours)
YouTube: GiveWell finds highly cost-effective charities — here’s how (good for the “why evidence?” mindset) (YouTube)
Optional alt (more “why give effectively” than GH-specific): Peter Singer TED talk (via The Life You Can Save) (The Life You Can Save)
Experiment B — longer exposure: understand the field with more granularity
(Non-EA but solid grounding) Coursera: An Introduction to Global Health (structured modules; builds vocabulary + systems map) (Coursera)
Crash Course playlist: Public Health (lighter but sticky; good for people who prefer video series) (YouTube)
Experiment C — pathway to doing a project (for proof-of-fit + momentum)
Best for: people who need action to stay motivated, want quick proof-of-fit, or need a push past impostor syndrome.
Here “measurable good” is often easiest via moving money effectively or creating a real-world mobilization, since many top orgs don’t offer easy small volunteer tasks.
Run a small fundraising/donation drive for GiveWell Top Charities / Top Charities Fund
Measurable outcome: $ donated (or matched) + number of donors. GiveWell explicitly routes donations to its recommended opportunities. GiveWell+2GiveWell+2
GWWC Pledge Drive as a community action experiment (measurable: pledges taken + giving committed). Giving What We Can+1
Experiment D — explore specific job boards (intuition + bridge to action)
80,000 Hours job board (good EA filter for high-impact roles) (80,000 Hours)
ReliefWeb jobs (humanitarian + development roles; good breadth) (ReliefWeb)
Devex job search (global development-focused job board) (Devex)
Impactpool (UN + international orgs; public health roles) (Impactpool)
Tiny scanning method (10–25 min): collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps → turn into one “direction to test” + one next step.
Card 1 — GiveWell top charities / Top Charities Fund
Toe in the water: read the top charities page; donate to Top Charities Fund or pick a charity. (GiveWell)
Card 2 — Giving What We Can: 10% Pledge
Toe in the water: take the pledge (or start with a smaller % if that’s what fits). (Giving What We Can)
Card 3 — Giving What We Can: Global Health & Wellbeing Fund
Toe in the water: donate once; it’s allocated periodically using evaluator input (incl. GiveWell). (Giving What We Can)
Card 4 — The Life You Can Save: recommended charities
Toe in the water: pick one recommended charity and read its “why recommended” page. (The Life You Can Save)
Fit gate: Selective + requires relocation (at least some in-person component)
Toe in the water: read the program flow + apply if it fits your timeline. (CE)
80,000 Hours – Global health (health in poor countries) problem profile:
YouTube – GiveWell explainer (“here’s how they do it”):
The Life You Can Save – Best charities:
Giving What We Can – Global Health & Wellbeing Fund:
Coursera – An Introduction to Global Health:
1) What it’s trying to achieve (plain language)

Rapidly reduce greenhouse gas emissions (and support adaptation where it’s most valuable) by pushing on the highest-leverage bottlenecks: policy, clean energy deployment, targeted innovation, and (in some cases) carbon removal. Both 80,000 Hours and Probably Good emphasize that career choice tends to matter more than personal footprint, and that some climate actions are much more effective than others. 80,000 Hours+1
Policy / government / regulation (often very leveraged; hard to attribute impact, but can be huge). Probably Good+1
Climate-focused engineering / tech (clean power, industrial decarbonization, storage, etc.). Probably Good+1
Research (climate science, modelling, carbon removal R&D, or “what actually works” analysis). 80,000 Hours+1
Climate finance / impact investing (moving large sums can matter; also easy to do “busy work,” so select carefully). Probably Good+1
Community / field-building (helping others enter or coordinate effectively). Work on Climate+1
Card 2 — 80,000 Hours: Climate change problem profile
Toe in the water: read “best ways of working” + note 2 levers you’d be willing to explore. 80,000 Hours
Card 3 — Work on Climate (Starter Packs + community)
Toe in the water: pick one Starter Pack (e.g., climate policy / solutions) and do the first 1–2 items. Work on Climate+1
Toe in the water: read the current “Top Climate Nonprofits” page; donate if that’s part of their plan. Giving Green+1
Card 5 — Founders Pledge Climate Fund / Climate Change Fund (via GWWC page)
Toe in the water: skim the executive summary + decide whether “giving” is a satisfying lever for them. Founders Pledge+2Giving What We Can+2
Toe in the water: look at syllabus + next cohort timing and see if it fits their timeline. Terra+1
Founders Pledge – Climate Change executive summary:
Giving What We Can – Founders Pledge Climate Change Fund page:
fitSignals: You’re willing to be a bit strategic (choosing which slice of climate to push on, not just “anything climate”). Probably Good+1
You can tolerate imperfect feedback loops (policy + systems change can be slow and hard to measure). Probably Good+1
You like high-leverage work: “one decision / one institution → very large downstream effects.”
Experiment A — introductory (< 1 hour): broad overview + test interest
Probably Good — Climate Change: Impact-Focused Overview (EA-ish framing + “what to do about it”). Probably Good
80,000 Hours — Climate change problem profile (skim summary + “best ways of working” sections). 80,000 Hours
Project Drawdown — Climate Solutions 101 (watch 1 episode that matches their curiosity). YouTube
Terra.do — “Climate Change: Learning for Action” (structured 12-week “map the space + find your role” style). Terra+1
Project Drawdown — Climate Solutions 101 playlist (self-paced series, broad but concrete). YouTube
Experiment C — pathway to doing a project (proof-of-fit + momentum)
Best for: people who need action early, want quick proof-of-fit, or need help bridging theory → concrete.
Work on Climate volunteering — explicitly recruits volunteers across functions (incl. research/data analytics), with the goal of mobilizing professionals into climate work. Work on Climate+1
If the person is giving-inclined: a giving drive informed by Giving Green research (measurable: $ influenced / donated). Giving Green+1
Experiment D — job-board exploration (intuition + bridge to action)
Probably Good job board (filtered to Climate Change) jobs.probablygood.org
80,000 Hours job board (fewer climate roles, but often higher “EA filter”). 80,000 Hours
Card 1 — Probably Good: Climate careers guide

name: Animal Welfare quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: 1) What it’s trying to achieve (plain language)
roleShapes: Research & analysis (what works, which tactics, which species/interventions)
Operations / management / fundraising (often a major bottleneck)
Animal x AI – different cause area
3) What a good fit often looks like (signals)
Strong “moral pull” toward animals + willingness to engage practical levers (institutions, corporations, policy)
Comfort with advocacy, persuasion, and coordination (many roles are people-facing)
Or: strong “evidence-minded” instinct (measurement, research, strategy) Faunalytics+1
80,000 Hours — Factory farming problem profile (skim; strong EA-style overview) 80,000 Hours
“Intro to effective animal advocacy” — Jacy Reese (EAGxBerkeley talk, YouTube) YouTube
Optional alt (if they’re more curious about wild animals specifically)
80,000 Hours — Wild animal welfare problem profile 80,000 Hours
Animal Advocacy Careers — Introduction to Animal Advocacy Online Course (structured, field-level map + careers) Effective Altruism+1
Optional alt (if they want “real field texture” through conversations)
80,000 Hours podcast episode with Lewis Bollard on factory farming advocacy 80,000 Hours
Experiment C — project pathway (make it concrete)
Faunalytics volunteering — volunteers work with staff on projects meant to support animal advocates (i.e., real external users). Faunalytics+1
Use Animal Advocacy Careers volunteer opportunities to find an org + role where your contribution is directly used (campaign support, research support, ops, comms, etc.). Animal Advocacy Careers+1

Pick one org type you’d be excited to support (campaign org / policy org / research org / ops-heavy nonprofit). Find 2–3 relevant roles on the job board and write 2 lines each: “why I could do this” + “what I’d need to learn.”
Animal Advocacy Careers job board (animal-advocacy specific) Animal Advocacy Careers
80,000 Hours job board (filter toward animal welfare / relevant ops/policy roles) 80,000 Hours
EA Opportunities board (broader: fellowships, events, short programs, etc.) Effective Altruism
Same as AI safety: collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 3 — 80,000 Hours: Wild animal welfare problem profile
Recommendation name: 80,000 Hours — Wild animal welfare problem profile
One-line pitch: Canonical EA overview for people pulled toward wild-animal suffering specifically.
Candidate is more interested in wild animals than farmed animals
Candidate is curious about “less intuitive” intervention space
Candidate is overwhelmed; start with factory farming or the video first
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Skim + note 3 intervention angles and whether each feels motivating or alienating.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 4 — Animal Advocacy Careers: Intro to Animal Advocacy Online Course
Recommendation name: Animal Advocacy Careers — Introduction to Animal Advocacy Online Course
One-line pitch: A structured course that maps the field and career options with more granularity.
Candidate wants structured learning and a map of roles/orgs
Candidate is interested but still fuzzy on “where I fit”
Candidate has near-zero bandwidth right now (start with Experiment A)
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Read the course page + confirm it fits your bandwidth this month.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 5 — 80,000 Hours podcast: Lewis Bollard on factory farming advocacy
Recommendation name: 80,000 Hours Podcast — Lewis Bollard on factory farm advocacy gains
One-line pitch: Practitioner “field texture” for understanding what progress looks like and why tactics work.
Candidate wants realism about advocacy and strategy
Candidate tends to over-consume content instead of acting (use C or D)
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Listen to the first ~30 minutes and extract 3 real-world constraints + 2 high-leverage roles.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
One-line pitch: Do externally useful work that animal advocates use (measurable good; not a portfolio exercise).
Candidate wants a concrete project with real beneficiaries
Candidate can’t commit to any deadlines at all right now
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Review volunteer options and draft a 3–5 sentence pitch: skills + a deliverable you can finish in 2–4 weeks.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 7 — Animal Advocacy Careers: Volunteer opportunities
Recommendation name: Animal Advocacy Careers — Animal volunteer opportunities
One-line pitch: A curated way to find volunteer roles where your work is directly used by real orgs.
Candidate wants hands-on impact now but doesn’t know which orgs exist
Candidate needs a push from “theory” to “concrete help”
Candidate isn’t ready to commit to anything ongoing (start with A/D)
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Pick 1 opportunity and send an application/message today (small + specific).
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 8 — Animal Advocacy Careers: Job board
Recommendation name: Animal Advocacy Careers — Job board
One-line pitch: The most field-specific way to see orgs/roles in animal advocacy and bridge interest → action.
Candidate wants to explore roles/orgs without committing yet
Candidate is motivated by concrete job examples
Candidate gets overwhelmed browsing listings (use advising or course instead)
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
10–25 min scan: collect 8–12 roles → label role types → circle 3 roles + 2 recurring skill gaps.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
One-line pitch: EA-filtered job board; good second lens for ops/policy/management roles relevant to animal orgs.
Candidate wants broader EA options, or is considering adjacent roles supporting animals
Candidate wants a second job-board lens
Candidate is early and would spiral from job listings
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Same scan method; then pick 1 role type to test via a conversation or volunteer task.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
One-line pitch: Broader than jobs: fellowships/events/short programs; useful as an “entry ramp.”
Candidate wants programs/fellowships more than job listings
Candidate gets overwhelmed by broad lists (pick one specific program instead)
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Search “animal welfare” and save 3 opportunities that match constraints/timeline.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 11 — Animal Advocacy Careers: Career advising
Recommendation name: Animal Advocacy Careers — Career advising
One-line pitch: Tailored guidance for navigating roles/orgs; great when someone feels stuck or uncertain.
Candidate is motivated but confused about fit/path
Candidate is progressing well self-directed and doesn’t want advising
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Apply for an advising call and share 2–3 directions you’re considering.
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 12 — Animal Charity Evaluators: Giving recommendations
Recommendation name: Animal Charity Evaluators — Recommended charities / funds
One-line pitch: Evidence-informed giving recommendations for animal welfare.
Candidate can’t shift career soon but wants an “impact now” lever
Candidate wants giving alongside career exploration
Candidate is donation-averse or it feels like pressure (offer as an option)
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Read the recommended list and choose a default giving option (even one-off).
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Card 13 — EA Funds: Animal Welfare Fund
Recommendation name: EA Funds — Animal Welfare Fund
One-line pitch: Expert-managed grantmaking fund; simple default option for effective giving.
Candidate wants giving as a complement to career work
Candidate wants direct control over where money goes (ACE may fit better)
Best “toe in the water” next step (≤60 min):
Skim the fund page and decide on a one-time or recurring donation (if giving fits).
Resources / links to support the next steps:
Jacy Reese – Intro to effective animal advocacy (YouTube):
80,000 Hours – Wild animal welfare problem profile:
Animal Advocacy Careers – Intro to Animal Advocacy online course:

name: Biosecurity
roleShapes: Technical work (biosurveillance, diagnostics, PPE/engineering controls, forecasting)
Research & analysis (risk assessment, program evaluation, modeling)
What a good fit often looks like (signals)
Motivated by preparedness + systems thinking (institutions, incentives, coordination)
Comfortable with policy/bureaucracy and/or technical public health work
Often benefits from “make it concrete” steps (projects, job-board scan), because the space can feel abstract
80,000 Hours Biorisk research, strategy & policy career review (read/skim as an overview entry point). 80,000 Hours
YouTube talk (EA-context): Jaime Yassif (biosecurity / GCBRs) talk (good “field picture” overview). YouTube
BlueDot Impact — Biosecurity course (structured ~30h exposure). BlueDot+1
Optional alt: pick 1–2 episodes/articles from 80,000 Hours’ biosecurity materials for deeper texture (e.g., health security interviews, misconceptions series). 80,000 Hours+280,000 Hours+2
Experiment C — project pathway (make it concrete)
Canonical pick: Oxford Biosecurity Group (OBG) projects (part-time remote research projects; biosecurity + AI-bio intersection). My Site+1
Toe-in-the-water step: browse the projects page; pick 2 projects that seem feasible/interesting; write 2 lines each.
80,000 Hours job board (filter toward biosecurity/pandemic preparedness roles). 80,000 Hours Job Board+1
Optional alt: EA Opportunities for events/fellowships/short programs in biosecurity. Effective Altruism
Tiny scanning method (10–25 min): same as AI safety (8–12 roles → label → circle 3 roles + 2 skill gaps).
fitSignals: Card 2 — Jaime Yassif: “Reducing global catastrophic biological risks” (YouTube)
Recommendation name: Jaime Yassif — Reducing global catastrophic biological risks (YouTube talk)
One-line pitch: A strong “field picture” intro from a leading practitioner; good for testing interest and getting intuition fast. YouTube+1
Candidate is new to biosecurity and wants an approachable overview
Candidate wants immediate structured learning + accountability (use BlueDot Biosecurity)
Watch and write 5 bullets: “what surprised me / what felt urgent / what role-types I can imagine.”
(Also appears in EA’s Biosecurity playlist.) YouTube
Recommendation name: BlueDot Impact — Biosecurity course
One-line pitch: A structured, cohort-based ~30-hour course aimed at understanding prevention/detection/response and identifying where you can contribute. BlueDot+1
Candidate is interested and wants structured exposure + peers
Candidate doesn’t yet know which sub-area to focus on
Candidate has near-zero bandwidth right now (use Experiment A first)
Commitment: Medium (5–15h/wk) (as a default; can be tuned)
Open the course page, skim curriculum, and sanity-check timing vs bandwidth.
Card 4 — 80,000 Hours: Biosecurity materials (topic archive / podcasts)
Recommendation name: 80,000 Hours — Biorisk strategy & policy topic archive (podcasts/resources)
One-line pitch: A curated list of deeper resources (often podcasts) for “field texture” and understanding real constraints/approaches. 80,000 Hours+1
Candidate liked Experiment A and wants more texture without committing to a course
Candidate tends to get lost in content consumption (use BlueDot or OBG instead)
Pick one episode from the archive and listen to the first 20–30 minutes; note 3 “real-world bottlenecks” that stood out.
Card 5 — Oxford Biosecurity Group (OBG): remote part-time projects
Recommendation name: Oxford Biosecurity Group — Projects
One-line pitch: Part-time remote research projects in biosecurity and AI×bio that aim to produce outputs with real downstream use (often with collaborating orgs/initiatives). My Site+2My Site+2
Candidate wants a concrete, externally useful project (measurable-good Experiment C)
Candidate benefits from structure/mentorship and a defined project scope
Candidate can’t sustain even part-time commitments or deadlines right now
Browse the projects page; pick 2 projects that seem feasible/interesting; write 2 lines each (why it matters + why you could contribute).
Card 6 — 80,000 Hours Job Board (filter to biosecurity & pandemic preparedness)
One-line pitch: High-signal job board for EA-aligned roles; useful both for job search and for building intuition about real orgs/roles in biosecurity. 80,000 Hours Job Board+1
Candidate wants to make opportunities concrete or is motivated by real openings
Candidate is ready to start seeing org landscape / role patterns
Candidate is very early and gets overwhelmed by job posts (use Experiment A first)
Use the scan method: collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.
Recommendation name: EA Opportunities — Biosecurity listings
One-line pitch: A broader opportunities surface (programs, fellowships, events) that often includes biosecurity-specific entry ramps beyond “jobs.” Effective Altruism+1
Candidate is earlier-stage and wants programs/fellowships
Candidate benefits from short structured opportunities rather than open-ended job search
Candidate gets overwhelmed by breadth (choose one concrete program card instead)
Search “biosecurity” and save 3 opportunities that match your constraints/timeline.
80,000 Hours — biorisk strategy & policy career paths:

name: Climate quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: 1) What it’s trying to achieve (plain language)
roleShapes: Policy / government / regulation (often very leveraged; hard to attribute impact, but can be huge). Probably Good+1
Climate-focused engineering / tech (clean power, industrial decarbonization, storage, etc.). Probably Good+1
Research (climate science, modelling, carbon removal R&D, or “what actually works” analysis). 80,000 Hours+1
Climate finance / impact investing (moving large sums can matter; also easy to do “busy work,” so select carefully). Probably Good+1
Community / field-building (helping others enter or coordinate effectively). Work on Climate+1
Candidate gets motivated by seeing real options
Candidate is easily overwhelmed by listings (do A first)
Toe in the water step (≤60 min):
Use the tiny scanning method (8–12 roles → label → circle 3 roles + 2 skill gaps → 1 direction + 1 next step).
One-line pitch: Big climate-specific job marketplace; good for breadth + pattern recognition on roles. Climatebase.org+1
Candidate wants a broad set of climate roles (tech/nonprofit/etc.)
Candidate is exploring “where could I fit?”
Candidate wants more EA-filtered roles first (use 80k job board)
Toe in the water step (≤60 min):
Save 10 roles; label role-types and extract 2 recurring skill gaps.
One-line pitch: Fewer climate listings, but often higher “EA filter” and good for adjacent high-impact roles. Climatebase.org
Candidate wants high-signal roles and is open to adjacent paths
Candidate wants climate-only breadth first (use Climatebase)
Toe in the water step (≤60 min):
Scan 8–12 roles → label → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps → convert to 1 direction + 1 next step.
Founders Pledge – Climate Change executive summary:
Giving What We Can – Founders Pledge Climate Change Fund page:
fitSignals: You’re willing to be a bit strategic (choosing which slice of climate to push on, not just “anything climate”). Probably Good+1
You can tolerate imperfect feedback loops (policy + systems change can be slow and hard to measure). Probably Good+1
You like high-leverage work: “one decision / one institution → very large downstream effects.”
Experiment A — introductory (< 1 hour): broad overview + test interest
Probably Good — Climate Change: Impact-Focused Overview (EA-ish framing + “what to do about it”). Probably Good
80,000 Hours — Climate change problem profile (skim summary + “best ways of working” sections). 80,000 Hours
Project Drawdown — Climate Solutions 101 (watch 1 episode that matches their curiosity). YouTube
Terra.do — “Climate Change: Learning for Action” (structured 12-week “map the space + find your role” style). Terra+1
Project Drawdown — Climate Solutions 101 playlist (self-paced series, broad but concrete). YouTube
Experiment C — pathway to doing a project (proof-of-fit + momentum)
Best for: people who need action early, want quick proof-of-fit, or need help bridging theory → concrete.
Work on Climate volunteering — explicitly recruits volunteers across functions (incl. research/data analytics), with the goal of mobilizing professionals into climate work. Work on Climate+1
If the person is giving-inclined: a giving drive informed by Giving Green research (measurable: $ influenced / donated). Giving Green+1
Experiment D — job-board exploration (intuition + bridge to action)
Probably Good job board (filtered to Climate Change) jobs.probablygood.org
80,000 Hours job board (fewer climate roles, but often higher “EA filter”). 80,000 Hours

name: Global Health & Development quick-start (v1)
overviewExcerpt: 1) What it’s trying to achieve (plain language)
roleShapes: Program implementation & field ops (distribution, logistics, monitoring)
Research & evaluation (development econ, epidemiology, cost-effectiveness, RCTs)
Policy and government implementation (health systems, procurement, public finance)
Entrepreneurship / founding new orgs (esp. “evidence-to-scale” nonprofits) (80,000 Hours)
3) What a “good fit” often looks like (signals)
You’re motivated by measurable impact and are OK with “unsexy” operational realities (supply chains, compliance, systems)
You like working with messy real-world constraints and still making steady progress
You enjoy evidence and tradeoffs (not only “what’s morally urgent” but also “what works”) (80,000 Hours)
Experiment A — introductory resource (< 1 hour): wide overview + test interest
80,000 Hours problem profile: Health in poor countries (Global health) (read/skim) (80,000 Hours)
YouTube: GiveWell finds highly cost-effective charities — here’s how (good for the “why evidence?” mindset) (YouTube)
Optional alt (more “why give effectively” than GH-specific): Peter Singer TED talk (via The Life You Can Save) (The Life You Can Save)
Experiment B — longer exposure: understand the field with more granularity
(Non-EA but solid grounding) Coursera: An Introduction to Global Health (structured modules; builds vocabulary + systems map) (Coursera)
Crash Course playlist: Public Health (lighter but sticky; good for people who prefer video series) (YouTube)
Experiment C — pathway to doing a project (for proof-of-fit + momentum)
Best for: people who need action to stay motivated, want quick proof-of-fit, or need a push past impostor syndrome.
Here “measurable good” is often easiest via moving money effectively or creating a real-world mobilization, since many top orgs don’t offer easy small volunteer tasks.
Run a small fundraising/donation drive for GiveWell Top Charities / Top Charities Fund
Measurable outcome: $ donated (or matched) + number of donors. GiveWell explicitly routes donations to its recommended opportunities. GiveWell+2GiveWell+2
GWWC Pledge Drive as a community action experiment (measurable: pledges taken + giving committed). Giving What We Can+1
Experiment D — explore specific job boards (intuition + bridge to action)
80,000 Hours job board (good EA filter for high-impact roles) (80,000 Hours)
ReliefWeb jobs (humanitarian + development roles; good breadth) (ReliefWeb)
Devex job search (global development-focused job board) (Devex)
Impactpool (UN + international orgs; public health roles) (Impactpool)
Tiny scanning method (10–25 min): collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps → turn into one “direction to test” + one next step.
